ygData.msgSnippet: ... I don t think it s as straightforward as that. Take XOR as an example. To solve XOR we need one hidden neuron with incoming connections from the two

Derek James wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Even with the blended runs the graphs in the paper show that the 
>>population now has a wide range of genomes from very simple ones 
>>to very complex (bloated) ones. 
>>    
>>
>
>Just because they're more complex, doesn't necessarily mean 
>they're "bloated".  It's only bloat if the added structure doesn't 
>carry with it proportional performance in fitness.
>  
>
I don't think it's as straightforward as that. Take XOR as an example. 
To solve XOR we need one hidden neuron with incoming connections from 
the two inputs. NEAT adds that neuron by splitting a connection. If we 
could now apply some function that highlights redundant structures we 
would see that the new connection is redundant - since it doesn't 
actually improve on the parent structure, not until a further mutation 
connects it to the other input.

Perhaps bloat is not the right word. My point is that some redundant 
structure is later connected too and made useful, but some will never be 
useful. We can't distinguish between what will and what won't be useful, 
so the concept of a phased search is basically allowing redundant 
structure to persist for some amount of time, and if it hasn't been 
incorporated into some useful structure after a certain number of 
generations then discard it. Thinking about it, you could achieve the 
same thing by giving each neuron and connection an age variable and then 
during a blended run you could only allow deletion on structures that 
have passed a certain age.

As NEAT stands, some non-useful structures might persist indefintately 
because they happned to be around on a genome that had some other 
improvements on it that made it very fit. These structures are what I 
would call bloat - they piggy back on good genomes, slowing them down. 
hmm, but actually I would imagine that these will eventually get their 
disbale bit set and so will not make it into the ANN's that are 
evaluated - but they are still in the genomes.

>>A phased search would periodically remove ALL redundancy 
>>from the entire population, thus improving the efficiency of a 
>>search 
>>from a computational expense point of view.  Now you could argue 
>>(Derek 
>>made this  point) that the 'trim' phase is going backwards in the 
>>search 
>>space and therefore it will take extra time to work back forwards 
>>again.
>>    
>>
>
>That's not exactly what I was arguing.  I was saying that if you do 
>two phases, only-complexifying followed by only-simplifying, that's 
>going to be less efficient than using both dynamics in the first 
>place.
>  
>
I honestly can't make a my mind up on this one. Conceptually I like the 
idea of trimming away all non-functional structures and cleanly 
re-starting the search, but whether it would actually be an improvement, 
or even a good idea I don't know.

>  
>
>>I believe that allowing the population to complexify/bloat 
>>unbounded is 
>>a very important part of the NEAT search process, but that it 
>>becomes 
>>detremental in medium to long searches. 
>>    
>>
>
>I don't think allowing liberal additions to the network at any stage 
>is very useful.  The whole philosophy of NEAT is that innovations 
>are added incrementally, and verified for usefulness along the way. 
>  
>
But not verified immediately,  if you did that you would only ever solve 
very simple problems.

>Again, the best approach would be to never let the junk pile up in 
>the first place.
>
>It seems intuitive that it's going to take longer to let junk pile 
>up and then clean it out, rather than never allowing it to pile up.
>  
>
But some junk may be a precursor to building some larger useful structure.

>>Get the search technique right/optimized first and THEN 
>>optimize the nuts and bolts code. 
>>    
>>
>
>I'd probably agree that optimizing the search is more important in 
>general than optimizing code...but they're both important.
>
>  
>
Agreed. There's no harm in working on two fronts.


One more thing I was thinking about while I'm here... I think there is 
one type of 'bloat' that single neuron/connection deletion doesn't 
tackle and that is connection chaining. Say a connection is performing a 
useful role and then we split it several times so that we have a long 
chain of neurons, but from a functional perspective it is just doing the 
job of a single connection. If you remove any one neuron/connection then 
you break the network's functionality. But if we were to intelligently 
eliminate neurons by shifting their connections to the source or target 
neuron then we could elmininate this kind of chain. Again though this 
sort of chain may form the basis of a future good structure so we 
wouldn't want to do this too aggresively - hence again my thinking that 
a phased search might work quite well.

Regards,

Colin




Colin.
